mainTopic.title: Nitric Oxide
mainTopic.content_info: The lecture handouts come with a lot of detailed information that is sufficient to cover the whole topic

quizzes.question: How is nitric oxide (NO) synthesized in vascular endothelial cells?
quizzes.goodAnswer: NO is synthesized from the terminal guanidine nitrogen of L-arginine and diffuses into vascular smooth muscle.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: NO is synthesized from carbon dioxide and water in vascular endothelial cells.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: NO is directly absorbed from the surrounding atmosphere by vascular endothelial cells.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: NO is synthesized from the terminal guanidine nitrogen of L-lysine in the liver.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: NO is synthesized through the cyclooxygenase pathway in vascular endothelial cells.

quizzes.question: What role does nitric oxide (NO) play in the pulmonary vasculature?
quizzes.goodAnswer: NO causes relaxation of pulmonary vascular smooth muscle, reducing pulmonary hypertension.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: NO causes contraction of pulmonary vascular smooth muscle, increasing pulmonary hypertension.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: NO causes oxidation of pulmonary endothelial cells, leading to increased vascular resistance.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: NO inhibits gas exchange in the alveoli, resulting in reduced oxygen uptake.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: NO binds to hemoglobin, reducing oxygen transport capacity.

quizzes.question: In ARDS, how does inhaled nitric oxide (NO) improve arterial oxygenation?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Inhaled NO improves ventilation-perfusion matching by causing selective vasodilation in well-ventilated lung regions.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Inhaled NO reduces oxygen consumption in body tissues, thereby increasing arterial oxygenation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Inhaled NO increases the solubility of oxygen in plasma, enhancing oxygen delivery to tissues.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Inhaled NO directly increases the production of red blood cells, improving oxygen transport.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Inhaled NO binds with carbon dioxide, reducing the respiratory stimulus and enhancing oxygen levels.

quizzes.question: Why is inhaled nitric oxide (NO) preferred over intravenous vasodilators in ARDS?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Inhaled NO does not produce systemic vasodilation and specifically targets ventilated alveoli.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Inhaled NO is cheaper and easier to administer than intravenous vasodilators.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Inhaled NO causes sustained systemic effects, unlike intravenous vasodilators.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Inhaled NO increases overall vascular resistance, unlike intravenous vasodilators.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Inhaled NO is less effective than intravenous vasodilators but has fewer side effects.

subTopics.title: Nitric Oxide inhalation in neonatal respiratory failure

quizzes.question: How does inhaled nitric oxide (NO) therapy benefit infants with persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN)?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Inhaled NO reduces pulmonary vascular resistance, improving systemic arterial oxygenation.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Inhaled NO increases systemic blood pressure, indirectly stimulating lung function.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Inhaled NO directly improves the muscle strength of the diaphragm, enhancing breathing.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Inhaled NO acts as a bronchodilator, opening airways in the upper respiratory tract.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Inhaled NO promotes surfactant production, thereby increasing lung compliance.

quizzes.question: What is a notable effect of inhaled nitric oxide (NO) in neonatal patients?
quizzes.goodAnswer: Inhaled NO selectively reduces pulmonary hypertension without systemic hypotension.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_1: Inhaled NO causes systemic hypotension, necessitating additional supportive therapy.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_2: Inhaled NO increases metabolic rate, thereby heightening oxygen demand.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_3: Inhaled NO increases heart rate, which improves oxygen delivery across the body.
quizzes.wrongAnswer_4: Inhaled NO exerts a strong immunosuppressive effect, reducing neonatal infections.
